title: 109_s863
content: The Act may be cited as the "Theodore Roosevelt Commemorative Coin Act". Theodore Roosevelt, born in 1858 in New York City, served in various roles including as a representative in the New York State Assembly, United States Civil Service Commissioner, Commissioner of the New York City Police Department, and Assistant Secretary of the Navy organizing the Rough Riders cavalry regiment. Theodore Roosevelt, also known as the "Rough Riders", served as Colonel during the Spanish-American War. He later became Governor of New York and then the 25th Vice-President of the United States. As the 26th President, he played a significant role in foreign affairs, making the US a world power and implementing reforms on labor, monopolies, and conservation. His commitment to conservation was influenced by his time as a rancher in North Dakota. Theodore Roosevelt, known as the "Conservationist President", established numerous reserves and parks during his presidency, totaling nearly 230 million acres of protected land. He was posthumously awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for his bravery in the Spanish-American War and was the first US citizen to receive the Nobel Peace Prize in 1906. Theodore Roosevelt was the first US citizen to receive the Nobel Peace Prize in 1906 for negotiating the 1905 peace treaty ending the Russo-Japanese War. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 silver coins with rough rider and adventurer designs, each weighing 26.73 grams, having a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Congress recommends striking the coins at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. Design Requirements for coins minted under this Act include being emblematic of President Theodore Roosevelt's life and legacy, using designs by James Earle Fraser or Augustus Saint-Gaudens, and featuring Theodore Roosevelt as a Rough Rider on the $1 coins. The reverse of the coins minted under section 3(a)(1) shall bear the eagle design from the $20 gold "double eagle" coin designed by Augustus Saint-Gaudens. The obverse of the coins minted under section 3(a)(2) shall bear the image of Theodore Roosevelt on horseback, based on James Earle Fraser's monumental bronze equestrian figure of Roosevelt at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City. The reverse of the coins minted under section 3(a)(2) shall bear a design based on James Earle Fraser's reverse designs for the Roosevelt Memorial Association Medal of Honor, depicting a flaming sword of righteousness and the quote "If I Must." The coins minted under this Act will bear inscriptions of the value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2006, with sales possible before that date. Minting authority will end on December 31, 2006. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Coins can be sold individually or as sets. Coins minted under this Act can be sold individually or as a set containing a coin of each design specified under section 4. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. The sales of coins minted under this Act require a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges received will be promptly paid to the Theodore Roosevelt Association for educational programs at Sagamore Hill National Historic Site and other curatorial activities. The Theodore Roosevelt Preservation Act allocates funds to institutions for the study and memory of Theodore Roosevelt and the Theodore Roosevelt Medora Foundation for educational programs at the Theodore Roosevelt National Park and other curatorial activities. The Theodore Roosevelt Preservation Act allocates surcharges to the Theodore Roosevelt Association and the Theodore Roosevelt Medora Foundation. The organizations are required to adhere to audit requirements under section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 8. CONTINUED ISSUANCE OF 5-CENT COINS MINTED IN 2004 AND 2005. The Secretary of the Treasury can issue numismatic items containing 5-cent coins minted in 2004 and 2005 after December 31, 2005. SEC. 9. LEWIS AND CLARK COIN AMENDMENTS. Section 308 of the Lewis and Clark Expedition Bicentennial Commemorative Coin Act is amended to allocate funds for activities related to commemorating the bicentennial of the expedition. One-half of the funds go to the National Council of the Lewis and Clark Bicentennial, and the other half to the Missouri Historical Society. Unexpended funds dispersed by the Secretary will be transferred accordingly. The unexpended funds from subsection (a) of the Lewis and Clark Expedition Bicentennial Commemorative Coin Act will be transferred to the Lewis and Clark Trail Heritage Foundation for stewardship of the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail. The Senate passed S. 863 on December 16, 2005, requiring the minting of coins to commemorate the centenary of President Theodore Roosevelt receiving the Nobel Peace Prize.
